title: 1718-A1
statement: A1. Burenka and Traditions (easy version)time limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputThis is the easy version of this problem. The difference between easy and hard versions is only the constraints on $$$a_i$$$ and on $$$n$$$. You can make hacks only if both versions of the problem are solved.Burenka is the crown princess of Buryatia, and soon she will become the $$$n$$$-th queen of the country. There is an ancient tradition in Buryatia — before the coronation, the ruler must show their strength to the inhabitants. To determine the strength of the $$$n$$$-th ruler, the inhabitants of the country give them an array of $$$a$$$ of exactly $$$n$$$ numbers, after which the ruler must turn all the elements of the array into zeros in the shortest time. The ruler can do the following two-step operation any number of times:select two indices $$$l$$$ and $$$r$$$, so that $$$1 \\le l \\le r \\le n$$$ and a non-negative integer $$$x$$$, thenfor all $$$l \\leq i \\leq r$$$ assign $$$a_i := a_i \\oplus x$$$, where $$$\\oplus$$$ denotes thebitwise XOR operation. It takes $$$\\left\\lceil \\frac{r-l+1}{2} \\right\\rceil$$$ seconds to do this operation, where $$$\\lceil y \\rceil$$$ denotes $$$y$$$ rounded up to the nearest integer.Help Burenka calculate how much time she will need.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 500$$$) — the number of test cases. The description of the test cases follows.The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 5000$$$) — the size of the array.The second line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$0 \\le a_i \\le 5000$$$) — elements of the array.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ in all tests does not exceed $$$5000$$$.OutputFor each test case, output a single number  — the minimum time that Burenka will need.ExampleInput745 5 5 531 3 220 032 5 761 2 3 3 2 11027 27 34 32 2 31 23 56 52 451822 1799 57 23 55Output2 2 0 2 4 7 4NoteIn the first test case, Burenka can choose segment $$$l = 1$$$, $$$r = 4$$$, and $$$x=5$$$. so it will fill the array with zeros in $$$2$$$ seconds.In the second test case, Burenka first selects segment $$$l = 1$$$, $$$r = 2$$$, and $$$x = 1$$$, after which $$$a = [0, 2, 2]$$$, and then the segment $$$l = 2$$$, $$$r = 3$$$, and $$$x=2$$$, which fills the array with zeros. In total, Burenka will spend $$$2$$$ seconds.

processed.result:
You are given an array of $n$ integers. You can perform the following operation any number of times:

1. Choose two indices $l$ and $r$ such that $1 \le l \le r \le n$.
2. Choose a non-negative integer $x$.
3. For all $l \le i \le r$, set $a_i = a_i \oplus x$, where $\oplus$ denotes the bitwise XOR operation.

It takes $\left\lceil \frac{r-l+1}{2} \right\rceil$ seconds to perform this operation.

Find the minimum time required to turn all elements of the array into zeros.

Input:

* The first line contains an integer $t$ ($1 \le t \le 500$) - the number of test cases.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains an integer $n$ ($1 \le n \le 5000$) - the size of the array.
    * The second line contains $n$ integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$ ($0 \le a_i \le 5000$) - the elements of the array.

Output:

For each test case, output a single number - the minimum time required.

You are given an array of numbers. You can perform an operation on a segment of the array, changing all the numbers in that segment by applying a bitwise XOR operation with a given number. The time it takes to perform this operation depends on the length of the segment. Find the minimum time to make all numbers in the array zero.
